author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Have a Good Trip’ and ‘Phantom India’
description: A documentary about celebrity experiences with hallucinogenic drugs drops on Netflix. And Louis Malle’s mammoth movie about India is available on the Criterion Channel.
content: HAVE A GOOD TRIP: ADVENTURES IN PSYCHEDELICS Stream on Netflix. The Broadway run of “Flying Over Sunset,” a musical that takes some artistic license with Cary Grant, Clare Boothe Luce and Aldous Huxley’s experiments with LSD, was suspended because of the coronavirus pandemic. But these pioneering celebrity psychonauts paved the way for others. In this new documentary, Sting, Sarah Silverman Paul Scheer and several other stars share their experiences with hallucinogenic drugs like acid and psilocybin mushrooms. Re-enactments and animated sequences help bring their reminiscences to life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Shooting of Ahmaud Arbery
description: A 25-year-old black man was pursued and killed. But no one was arrested until a video of the confrontation was released months later.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keren Landman
title: Growing Up Alongside a Sibling With a Disability
description: When children help with the education of a brother or sister with special needs, the outcomes are often good for both.
content: Not long after my mother learned that my brother, David, was autistic, she began what she called “little school”: sessions in which she taught him to draw faces, cut with scissors, read and cook. He was 4, I was 2. I recently asked her how she balanced David’s needs with mine. “You were the teacher’s assistant,” she said. “I was trying to make you feel important.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Have a Good Trip’ Review: Stars Tell Their Groovy Acid Tales
description: Netflix’s drug story compendium is like a long, awkward hang in your dealer’s grimy apartment.
content: Few things are funnier to a person than their own drug stories — or as unfunny to pretty much anyone else. This is the central conundrum of “Have a Good Trip: Adventures in Psychedelics” (now streaming on Netflix), a giggly compendium — “documentary” seems generous — of actors, musicians, comedians and writers telling their best drug stories. Some are accompanied by cheerful animations, others by strained re-enactments; all are soaked in good vibes. One of the first subjects, Sting, begins his interview by announcing, “I wouldn’t want this to be an exercise in the Just Say No campaign.” There is, to put it mildly, no danger of that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Best Baked Beans
description: Ali Slagle’s cheesy, spicy black bean bake is a great feed, and even better with a little bit of crisp bacon crumbled on top.
content: Good morning. With the assistance of his young student Titian, Giovanni Bellini made a painting in 1514, “The Feast of the Gods.” It’s terrific and someday maybe you’ll see it for real at the National Gallery in Washington, D.C. They’re all there: Mercury, Jupiter, Cybele, Pan, Neptune, the whole gang. Everyone’s drinking wine, eating, hanging out, and even if creepy Priapus is about to try to grope a sleeping Lotis (in the story, he fails and everyone laughs at him), it’s still a nice image of what it’s like, what it was like, to gather a lot of people together to celebrate nothing in particular. Someday, some way, we may do that again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Follow the Silk Road, Book by Book
description: Compiled by our contributors, a reading list for recreating the ancient trade route from the comfort of home.
content: This year, T’s spring Travel issue is devoted to just five stories, each an account of its writer’s journey along a different section of the Silk Road — the ancient network of trade routes that until the 15th or 16th century spanned some 4,000 miles of the globe, from Central Asia across the Middle East to Southern Europe, and formed a vital conduit for both new commodities and new ideas. While venturing to faraway places might seem like a distant possibility now, a year after this issue began to take shape, as we reckon with the global pandemic, these pieces are a powerful reminder of our innate desire to move and explore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: What to Watch on Netflix to Help Language Learning
description: Supplement your app study with these excellent non-English movies and TV shows.
content: Maybe you’ve decided to learn a foreign language during lockdown and have downloaded a language app like Duolingo, which saw its numbers double in March to around 30 million monthly users. You may now be able say useful phrases, like “My horse eats eggs” and “My sister is not in the park,” in French, German, Italian or Spanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: New Workhorses for Your Spice Drawer
description: Burlap and Barrel now sells a fundamentals collection, with six everyday spices to elevate your cooking.
content: Now that you’re stuck indoors, have you reorganized your spice rack? (It’s a great project to tackle with kids: They can tell you which tin of paprika or curry has faded in color or aroma and needs replacing.) And while you’re at it, maybe it’s time for a real upgrade. Burlap & Barrel, a spice importer specializing in fine, single-origin products, now offers an assortment they call Fundamentals Collection, six spices that will take you through the major demands of everyday cooking without wandering toward wild Icelandic kelp or Euphrates mint leaves. Turkish hyssop thyme has the herbal profile of thyme with a spicy anise cast; Vietnamese royal cinnamon is deeply aromatic; Afghan wild mountain cumin is finely textured, pungent and hardly needs grinding; smoked pimentón paprika has an abiding sweetness; Turkish silk chili delivers moderate heat and saltiness; and fine-textured purple garlic powder is sharply pungent, making it unlike the supermarket variety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Kenny Chesney’s No. 1 Album Reopens Debate Over Ticket Bundles
description: The country star’s “Here and Now” beat Drake’s “Dark Lane Demo Tapes,” but Chesney’s tally was bolstered by sales from tickets to now-postponed concerts.
content: Last year, Billboard magazine came under intense criticism over how its charts accounted for sales bundles — when artists tack a copy of their new album as a bonus for buying a T-shirt or other merchandise, or a concert ticket. Long a useful marketing tool, bundles have run rampant in the streaming age, leading to concerns about chart manipulation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The G.O.P.’s Pandemic Playbook
description: Republicans can flip a House seat in California, but they’re raising doubts about the voting anyway.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Cities We Need
description: Crises can be clarifying.
content: In the first half of the 20th century, the students at Boston’s best public high school, Boston Latin, included a brash kid named Leonard Bernstein, who would one day compose West Side Story; another boy named Thomas L. Phillips, who would build the Massachusetts manufacturer Raytheon into a bulwark of American defense; and Paul Zoll, who would pioneer the use of electricity to treat cardiac arrest while working as a doctor at a Boston hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: 5 Hurt in Texas Park Crowded With Hundreds of People, Police Say
description: It was not clear what such a large crowd was doing at the park in Fort Worth during the pandemic, the police said. Witnesses told officials at least 30 gunshots were heard.
content: Five people were injured on Sunday night at a Fort Worth park crowded with hundreds of people, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Zlatan Ibrahimovic Returns to Milan; Fans Return to Taiwan Baseball
description: No, Ibrahimovic is not returning to play soccer in Sweden, his home country. Plus: A top soccer team in China folds, and fans return (carefully) to the baseball stands in Taiwan.
content: Swedish soccer fans had been hoping that the strange circumstances of the coronavirus pandemic would have a surprising side effect: the return of striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic to his home country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: App Shows Promise in Tracking New Coronavirus Cases, Study Finds
description: The app, which allows people to record their symptoms, was remarkably effective in predicting infections. The most reliable indicators, researchers found, were loss of smell and taste.
content: In the absence of widespread on-demand testing, public health officials across the world have been struggling to track the spread of the coronavirus pandemic in real time. A team of scientists in the United States and the United Kingdom says a crowdsourcing smartphone app may be the answer to that quandary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: G.O.P. Split Over State Aid That Could Mostly Go to Democratic Strongholds
description: With governors and mayors pressing for more federal help to deal with the effects of the pandemic, a divide among Republicans is being driven by the political bent of the states that stand to benefit.
content: WASHINGTON — When Senator Mitt Romney of Utah strode into a luncheon with fellow Republicans last week, he was carrying an oversize poster in his black-gloved hand that bore a blunt message: “Blue states aren’t the only ones who are screwed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
title: Bafflement Greets Boris Johnson’s Plan for Reopening Britain
description: Critics say the government has failed to answer some basic questions. Among them: 1) when to return to work and 2) how to get there.
content: LONDON — When the coronavirus first struck, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain agonized long and hard before closing stores, pubs and restaurants as part of the country’s fight against the disease. But with the spread of the virus now curbed, easing the lockdown is proving harder still.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: With states reopening without meeting safety criteria, a surge of new cases may be on the way before the autumn.
content: Dozens of U.S. states are starting to reopen their economies, hoping to ease the economic pain brought on by pandemic-fighting restrictions. But by doing it now — before meeting even minimal criteria for a safe reopening — they are inviting disaster, our science reporter Donald G. McNeil Jr. writes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: What to Do With 50 Pounds of Potatoes? The Quandaries of Bulk Buying
description: The pandemic has turned many cooks into big-volume shoppers, and left them puzzling out how to manage a bursting pantry of ingredients.
content: Elysia Mann never thought she’d see the day when her regular trips to the grocery store became a wistful memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Fauci, Other Witnesses and Chairman Are Quarantined, but Hearing Must Go On
description: Tuesday’s hearing before the Senate Health Committee will be a chance for Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and other top health experts to speak to lawmakers, albeit by video, without President Trump nearby.
content: WASHINGTON — The chairman is in quarantine for coronavirus exposure. So are the star witnesses. But fireworks — albeit virtual ones — are likely when Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and three other top government doctors testify before the Senate Health Committee on Tuesday in one of the strangest high-stakes hearings in memory.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tesla to Restart Bay Area Factory in Defiance of Local Order
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: New York to Begin Limited Reopening in Upstate Region
description: Parts of New York that have met seven health and testing criteria will be allowed to restart construction, manufacturing and curbside retail.
content: In the most concrete step toward restarting his battered and shuttered state, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that large chunks of New York State’s central interior will be allowed to partially reopen construction, manufacturing and curbside retail this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tesla to Restart Bay Area Factory in Defiance of Local Order

content: Elysia Mann never thought she’d see the day when her regular trips to the grocery store became a wistful memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: Victim or Executioner? Let the Computer Decide
description: An interactive plan for a Holocaust museum envisioned sorting visitors into victims, executioners and collaborators. Backlash ensued.
content: MOSCOW — It probably seemed like a good idea at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Renneisen
title: Three Weeks in April: An E.M.T. Crew Faces Exhaustion, Isolation and Death
description: A photojournalist switched careers and became an E.M.T. just months before the coronavirus pandemic hit. Recently, he brought his camera along to document what he and his crew are seeing.
content: After three years living in Nairobi, Kenya, working as a photojournalist throughout Africa and the Middle East, I decided I wanted to move home and pursue a career in public safety. I had always been interested in emergency medicine and was an emergency medical technician  in college, so I got recertified and was hired by Empress Emergency Medical Service in a suburb of New York City last September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isadora Kosofsky
title: After Months Apart, Mother’s Day Visits Through a Doorway
description: At a Los Angeles nursing home, families got their first chance to see Mom since the lockdown began — as long as they stayed outside, and she stayed in.
content: LOS ANGELES — Jackelyn Brown had not laid eyes on her 104-year-old mother, Grace, since March 11. She used to visit every day, but the coronavirus outbreak had put a stop to that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: For the Public Library, Martha Graham Is the Missing Link
description: The library has acquired Graham’s archive, filling a significant gap in the story of early modern dance in America.
content: “Why don’t we have Martha?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Social-Distancing Shamers Are Watching
description: The internet has long been identified as a breeding ground for public shaming, but the coronavirus has advanced the game.
content: It was 80 degrees and sunny in New York City, so I was lying slack on the couch, scrolling aimlessly through my phone, when I paused on a photograph shot a few miles away. A throng of people were sunbathing on the green lawn of a Manhattan pier. In the center stood a man in a pair of floral briefs and nothing else. With his arms akimbo and his chin turned artfully to the side, he looked as if he were posing in a bodybuilding lineup. In front of him was a woman with her face thrown up to the sky, her hands rising as if to tousle her hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Gone From Grocery Shelves, Now There’s a Mad Dash to Find Them
description: Here’s why some everyday staples have disappeared from shelves as the crisis changes how people shop and eat.
content: The fallout from the coronavirus hit Allison Arevalo when she could no longer find pasta at the supermarket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: In Jerry Stiller, the Rage of Jewish Fathers Found a Hilarious Outlet
description: The comic actor’s rat-a-tat timing and bristling bass reminded us why we loved those strange, embarrassing relatives.
content: Every time Jerry Stiller opened his mouth on “Seinfeld,” it made me laugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Coronavirus, U.K. Quarantine, Climate Change: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: How the ‘Outlander’ Team Managed That Shocking Season Finale
description: Caitriona Balfe, Diana Gabaldon and the showrunner Matthew B. Roberts discussed the centrality of sexual violence to the story and their attempts to portray it meaningfully.
content: This interview includes spoilers for the Season 5 finale of “Outlander.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.8 Million in California
description: A 1938 storybook home in Mill Valley, a new house in San Jose and a midcentury hacienda in Pasadena.
content: A 1938 storybook home in Mill Valley, a new house in San Jose and a midcentury hacienda in Pasadena.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Praying for Child Care
description: When will anyone else be able to watch our children?
content: A few weeks ago, my 3-year-old discovered that she could initiate FaceTime calls on her own. She can’t read, but she can identify the avatars of her grandparents, aunts and uncles, and her dad’s goofiest friends from a purloined iPad. At first this was mildly alarming — how long before my 3-year-old FaceTimes one of our bosses, or some rando we met once in 2007 whose number is still in our contact list? But with minor supervision we realized that we could pawn her and her big sister off on physically distant relatives for 30 minute spurts, and get a much-needed break for ourselves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Rethink Your Wedding
description: It can still be great. First, do not panic.
content: Let’s just be real. If your wedding was planned as a big gathering in the next couple weeks (probably even months), and you don’t want to cancel, now is the time to pivot to a virtual ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Rethink Your Wedding
description: It can still be great. First, do not panic.
content: Let’s just be real. If your wedding was planned as a big gathering in the next couple weeks (probably even months), and you don’t want to cancel, now is the time to pivot to a virtual ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will McCarthy
title: Another Covid-19 Loss? The Jumping Frog Jubilee
description: Monday: In Angels Camp, a tradition is disrupted. Also: An election update.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Mozambique?
description: Can you find Mozambique on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 30 million people?
content: Can you find Mozambique on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 30 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Eating in Xi’an, Where Wheat and Lamb Speak to China’s Varied Palette
description: In the city’s Muslim Quarter, meals are a celebration of globalization and ethnic diversity — and a lasting defense against erasure.
content: IN THE VAST departure hall of Shanghai’s decade-old Hongqiao Railway Station, an epic writ in 80,000 tons of steel, everything looks new and tired at once, tinged with gray — even the October sunshine that filters down from skylights so high it can’t quite reach the floor. This is architecture meant to set the soul asoar, but I am conscious only of how far I am below, in the horde at the gates. Down the stairs, the bullet train waits, sleek-nosed and sealed in on itself, like a missile. A stoic janitor steers a Zamboni-like machine down the platform, buffing it to a gleam. When the train sets off, it feels like nothing: the slight give of a door unlatched. If I don’t look out the window, I can imagine myself absolutely still.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esi Edugyan
title: How Silk-Making Represents a More Hidden Side of Georgia’s Past
description: The sumptuous craft was introduced along the country’s trade routes centuries ago. Even now, links to this delicate tradition still remain.
content: 1. TBILISI RISES OUT of the steep banks of the Mtkvari, in Georgia, spread wide on either side of the river like hands cupping a bowl — a city of cobblestones, winding lanes and wrought-iron gates bleeding rust. It is filled with the particular decay of the old Soviet republics, and the air smells of fresh bread, hot herb soup and scorched motor oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Little Richard Wasn’t Conceited. He Was Underappreciated.
description: After his career in music, the rock ’n’ roll innovator took up the task of maintaining his legacy — because nobody else was going to do it.
content: Alarm was central to the Little Richard experience. He wailed like a siren and screamed for his life. Every song was an emergency, every punched and pounded piano key an ecstatic dialing of 9-1-1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Natural Gas Exports Slow as Pandemic Reduces Global Demand
description: Businesses in the United States, Israel and other countries were planning to invest billions in export terminals. Now, those projects are being canceled or delayed.
content: HOUSTON — A few months ago, Israel and some Arab countries were laying the groundwork for an energy partnership that held the potential for economic cooperation between once-hostile neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Jack Healy
title: Tribal Nations Face Most Severe Crisis in Decades as the Coronavirus Closes Casinos
description: Nearly 500 tribal casinos remain shut down during the pandemic, causing job losses to spike. The economic damage is spreading quickly, wreaking havoc on fragile tribal finances.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — Tribal nations around the United States are facing their most severe crisis in decades as they grapple simultaneously with some of the deadliest coronavirus outbreaks in rural America and the economic devastation caused by the protracted shutdown of nearly 500 tribally owned casinos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Joe Ward
title: Can the N.F.L. Really Return to Normal This Fall?
description: Before the N.F.L. can begin the season as planned in September, it must first figure out how to safely open team facilities for training camps in mid-July.
content: Even as the coronavirus continued to ravage American communities, the N.F.L. last week released a full schedule of games that on the surface included no obvious backup plan in case the pandemic prevents the season from starting on Sept. 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: A Coronavirus Mystery Explained: Moscow Has 1,700 Extra Deaths
description: Russia’s government has boasted of a low coronavirus mortality rate, but figures from an obscure city agency cast doubt on those claims.
content: MOSCOW — Ever since the coronavirus took hold globally, researchers have been puzzled by Russia’s mortality rate of only about 13 deaths per million, far below the world average of 36 in a country with an underfunded health system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: NBC Trades Radio City for a Livestream to Give Advertisers a Taste of Fall
description: Well, there was a trailer for one new show: “Mr. Mayor,” a sitcom co-created by Tina Fey and starring Ted Danson.
content: There were two celebrity cameos, one trailer and no scheduling announcements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Frakt
title: Putting a Dollar Value on Life? Governments Already Do
description: Trade-offs are routine in health policy, and the math and analysis underlying them have been around for decades.
content: How much money is a life worth?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: This Afghan General Fought the Taliban for Years. Now He Has Joined Them.
description: Another influential family was split by the war when a retired province police chief defected to the insurgency. His son remains deputy governor.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — As a onetime police chief of the restive province of Farah in western Afghanistan, Gen. Abdul Jalil Bakhtawar was a dogged enemy of the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: M.L.B. Proposes an 82-Game Season Starting in July
description: The proposal, which would require approval from the players’ union, would have teams start the season in early July and mainly play teams in their geographic region.
content: Major League Baseball has formalized its plan to return to the field, with teams agreeing Monday on a proposal to send to the players’ union for an 82-game season that would start without fans in early July. The plan would include an expanded playoff field and the designated hitter for all games, even those in the National League, where it is not typically used.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Why Kamala Harris Isn’t Clamoring to Be Biden’s Running Mate
description: The California senator is considered a potential running mate for Joe Biden. But unlike other possible contenders, she has avoided making a pitch for the ticket.
content: Six years ago, when President Barack Obama had to replace his departing attorney general, he offered the job to Kamala Harris, who led the California Justice Department — the first woman to occupy that role in its history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Weighs Whether Much of Oklahoma Is an Indian Reservation
description: The answer to the question could have vast implications for criminal prosecutions and for commerce.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday about whether much of eastern Oklahoma is an Indian reservation, a question that could have enormous consequences for the area’s 1.8 million residents in matters of criminal justice and commerce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
title: Killing of Ahmaud Arbery Is Switched to a Fourth Prosecutor
description: Joyette M. Holmes, an Atlanta-area district attorney, will take over a case that has stirred protests, as the Justice Department said it was weighing federal hate crimes charges.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — The Georgia attorney general on Monday named a new prosecutor to oversee the case of Ahmaud Arbery, the 25-year-old black man whose killing has drawn national attention and inspired protests after a video emerged of his fatal encounter with two white men who have been charged with murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Maggie Haberman
title: Biden and Trump Teams Each Raised Over $60 Million in April
description: President Trump and the Republicans, who brought in slightly more, maintain a vast cash advantage. But Mr. Biden’s substantial haul is likely to buoy Democrats who are worried about his ability to compete financially.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democratic National Committee raised more than $60 million in April, a substantial haul that may help soothe Democrats’ worries about Mr. Biden’s ability to compete financially with President Trump and the Republicans despite their vast cash advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Comedy We Need Right Now
description: An aspiring comedian says there’s “something powerful about seeing comedians filming from their living rooms.” Also: Write that love letter; staying united; book-banning in Alaska.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: New British Guidelines Sow Confusion
description: As France, Russia and others eased restrictions, Germany watches warily as the rate the virus is spreading has risen there. And in Mexico City, while other sounds are muffled, street musicians play on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: As States Rush to Reopen, Scientists Fear a Coronavirus Comeback
description: Officials are under pressure to restart the economy, but many states are moving too quickly, researchers say. The costs may be measured in lost lives.
content: Millions of working people and small-business owners who cannot earn money while sheltering at home are facing economic ruin. So dozens of states, seeking to ease the pain, are coming out of lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacey Stowe
title: A Drive-By Art Show Turns Lawns and Garages Into Galleries
description: The outdoor exhibition on Long Island featured works installed at properties from Hampton Bays to Montauk, with social isolation as just one theme.
content: No one was supposed to get too close to each other over the weekend during a drive-by exhibition of works by 52 artists on the South Fork of Long Island — a dose of culture amid the sterile isolation imposed by the pandemic. But some people couldn’t help themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: For Your Ears Only: Broadway’s New Stage Is a Mic
description: With theaters shuttered, a host of audio dramas and musicals have popped up, and actors are honing a skill: creating characters with just their voices.
content: “You have to make your voice do everything,” James Monroe Iglehart said. If you have seen Iglehart onstage — as the genie in “Aladdin,” say, or as Jefferson in “Hamilton” — you will have admired his nifty footwork and kinetic facial expressions. Those don’t matter now. In his apartment, in front of his “really expensive” microphone, he creates characters with vocals alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Coronavirus, Iran, Jerry Stiller: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: For almost two months, the killing of Ahmaud Arbery received very little attention. Over the past two weeks, it has become a subject of national outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.8 Million Homes in California
description: A 1938 storybook home in Mill Valley, a new house in San Jose and a midcentury hacienda in Pasadena.
content: Mill Valley, a Marin County city 14 miles north of San Francisco, has long been popular with Bay Area residents seeking access to nature. In the early 20th century, the Mount Tamalpais and Muir Woods Railway transported tourists from downtown Mill Valley to the eastern peak of Mount Tamalpais, and by the mid-20th century the city had become a magnet for Bay Area artists and musicians. This house is a 10-minute drive from the Muir Woods National Monument and about half an hour from Stinson Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: Voices From the Pandemic’s Front Lines
description: Scores of Times staff members worked to present the stories of doctors, nurses and other health care professionals who are risking everything to care for Covid-19 patients.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said  38 New York City children had been diagnosed with an inflammatory syndrome that appears  linked to the coronavirus.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Monday’s Livestreaming Events: Frieze Art Fair and a Talk With André Holland
description: Appointment viewing is back. Find out what online events to look for today, and when to tune in.
content: Here are a few of the best events happening on Monday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Big Tech Has Crushed the News Business. That’s About to Change.
description: News organizations have long hoped that tech platforms would pay them for news. Now regulators abroad are moving to make that happen.
content: It reads like a coroner’s report on the news business, 623 pages filled with charts and graphs detailing the devastating decline in local news and public policy reporting of the past decade. It landed on the Australian prime minister’s desk last summer, unnoticed by most news consumers in America and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Coziest Vegetable-and-Sausage Soup for Those Chilly May Days
description: Make a big pot, brimming with roots and greens from the crisper, for a little bit of comfort.
content: Winter has not released its grip on us here in the Northeast, with cold, rainy days peppering the week even this late in May. And that means I’m still making big pots of hearty, warming soup, using all the odds and ends from the refrigerator and freezer. It’s a time-honored strategy that always produces the best soup, brimming with vegetables and bits of sausage, and bolstered by some homemade chicken broth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: No Natural Light? No Problem
description: Fake plants are bringing some joy to homebound lives.
content: People are finding all sorts of ways to pass the time in isolation: working on 3,000-piece jigsaw puzzles, stress-baking bread, watching celebrities practice social distancing in their sunlit, open-plan homes filled with thriving houseplants and surrounded by immaculate landscaping. If you’d resisted plant mania before, you may now see that empty corner of your apartment as the perfect spot for a fiddle leaf fig.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: A Dream Commute from Weehawken
description: Downsizing from a suburban family home in New Jersey to a waterfront apartment gave one commuter back several hours of her life every day.
content: In the fall of 2018, Connie Klube traded a commute from New Jersey that would sometimes devour three hours of her day for one that takes less than half an hour each way and includes a pleasant ferry ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: No Prince Without the King
description: The pompadour, the pancake, the pantsuits, the pink — in style as in music, Little Richard led the way.
content: As he himself would have been the first to say, everything began with Little Richard — not just rock ’n’ roll but gender bending as showmanship, self-mythology as an art form, drag in the middle of Main Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Chatterton Williams
title: I Didn’t Feel Parisian Until I Escaped Paris
description: There's nothing more French than descending on the countryside in times of trouble.
content: There's nothing more French than descending on the countryside in times of trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Chocolate and Cheese, if You Please
description: Websites help shoppers find mail-order cheeses, chocolates, farmers and purveyors.
content: Closed stores and restaurants are also taking a toll on parts of the food industry, like cheesemakers, as they lose the normal outlets for their perishable products. Your local cheese shop should be your first stop, but, on Janet Fletcher’s Planet Cheese website, there’s a national list of the cheesemakers and retailers that ship their products, a good resource for shoppers. Similarly, the Fine Chocolate Industry Association, whose members mostly offer bean-to-bar confections, has a list of chocolate makers that sell online at Make Mine Fine. Lastly, Good Food Media Network, which publishes a restaurant guide called Good Food 100 Restaurants, has created an umbrella website, updated weekly, that includes farms, purveyors like Island Creek Oysters, producers like Anson Mills and several wineries, and distributors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Now From Mexico: Corn Whiskey
description: Abasolo Ancestral Corn Whisky, made from nixtamalized corn, has a toasty aroma and some honeyed sweetness.
content: We appreciate tequila, have tried mezcal and are sampling sotol. Still there is more to learn about Mexican spirits. Corn whiskey, for example, is a rarity. But now there’s one that’s new. Abasolo, El Whisky de Mexico, from Jilotepec de Abasolo, just north of Mexico City, is made entirely from heritage corn that has undergone nixtamalization, like masa. The 86-proof spirit — made in copper pot stills and aged in oak — is pale gold, has a toasty aroma and some honeyed sweetness that tames the alcohol. It’s excellent with a splash of pineapple juice and a squeeze of lime. Through Aug. 1, the profits from sales are being donated to Another Round Another Rally, a nonprofit based in Phoenix that supports the hospitality industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: The Defense Rests? Scott Turow’s Favorite Lawyer Is 85 and Still Arguing
description: In “The Last Trial,” Turow’s recurring character Sandy Stern defends a Nobel-winning doctor against charges of murder and insider trading.
content: The title of Scott Turow’s true-to-form, pleasingly substantial “The Last Trial” is only one of the book’s hints that something will be coming to an end here. That something is the 60-year career of Alejandro Stern, better known as Sandy, a character who has appeared in every Turow novel. Turow adores Sandy but has given him only one chance to hold center stage. That was 30 years ago, in “The Burden of Proof.” Now it’s time for the curtain call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Nashville N.A.A.C.P. Leader Finds Bull’s-Eye in His Yard
description: A suspect has been charged in the case, and the police have set up a mediation between the Rev. Keith Caldwell  and a police officer who he said was dismissive of the matter.
content: The leader of the Nashville chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. walked out of his house on Saturday night to find that someone had propped up a bull’s-eye target in his yard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Jeffrey Katzenberg Blames Pandemic for Quibi’s Rough Start
description: Downloads of the $1.8 billion short-form streaming app, meant for phones, are paltry. “I attribute everything that has gone wrong to coronavirus,” Mr. Katzenberg said. “Everything.”
content: LOS ANGELES — Jeffrey Katzenberg hasn’t left his Beverly Hills home in nearly 50 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Why Economic Pain Could Persist Even After the Pandemic Is Contained
description: Plunging revenue at many businesses, whether they close or not, could ripple through the economy and block a quick return to prosperity.
content: The one great reason for economic optimism during this pandemic is that once public health concerns are addressed, the economy could quickly return to something like pre-crisis levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: The ‘Festivus Miracle’ Lives On
description: The anti-holiday holiday, made famous by Jerry Stiller in his role as Frank Costanza, is still celebrated by fans who also find tinsel distracting.
content: The legacies of Jerry Stiller, the comic actor who died Monday, are many. But perhaps few will be as durable as the holiday tradition that began as a joke and spread after his signature character, Frank Costanza, began singing its many virtues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
title: Wuhan Cases, India’s Trains, Silk Road: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Emily Cochrane
title: As Banks Stumble in Delivering Aid, Congress Weighs Other Options
description: Accounts provided by the Federal Reserve and distributions handled by payroll processors are among the ideas floating around Capitol Hill.
content: When the federal government agreed to funnel $2.2 trillion in emergency aid to Americans devastated by the economic shutdown, the nation’s banks were given a central role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump’s Taxes and the Supreme Court: What You Need to Know
description: The court will hear highly anticipated arguments over whether the president’s accountants and bankers must disclose information about his financial affairs.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on Tuesday on whether President Trump can block the release of his financial records, setting the stage for a ruling on the power of presidents to resist demands for information from prosecutors and Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Shanghai Disneyland Reopens With Strict Safety Procedures
description: Limited capacity, face masks and plastic gloves to ride: The opening offers a glimpse of how other Disney parks may cope.
content: The elephants are flying again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Ex-Justice Dept. Officials Lash Out at Barr Over Flynn and Stone Cases
description: The attorney general’s interventions damaged the Justice Department, argued the former officials, who were directly involved in the cases of the two Trump allies.
content: WASHINGTON — Two former law enforcement officials involved in the cases of the onetime Trump advisers Michael T. Flynn and Roger J. Stone Jr. attacked Attorney General William P. Barr’s extraordinary intervention in the inquiries, condemning his moves as detrimental to the rule of law and to public confidence in the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iranian Friendly Fire Kills 19 in 2nd Missile Accident of Year
description: One Iranian ship reportedly fired on another during military exercises. It was one more public relations disaster for Iran’s military.
content: For the second time this year, Iran appears to have fired a missile at the wrong target with deadly consequences, raising questions about its ability to control its weapons and increasing tensions in the Persian Gulf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Chatterton Williams
title: I Didn’t Feel Parisian Until I Escaped Paris
description: There's nothing more French than descending on the countryside in times of trouble.
content: There's nothing more French than descending on the countryside in times of trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump’s Taxes and the Supreme Court: What You Need to Know
description: The court will hear highly anticipated arguments over whether the president’s accountants and bankers must disclose information about his financial affairs.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on Tuesday on whether President Trump can block the release of his financial records, setting the stage for a ruling on the power of presidents to resist demands for information from prosecutors and Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katey Rusch and Casey Smith
title: How Do You Enforce a Law That Tramples the Land of the Free?
description: Angela Alvarado, a veteran prosecutor in the Santa Clara district attorney’s office in California, has to weigh safety, freedom and the law as she fields complaints about stay-at-home violations.
content: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — A veteran prosecutor in Northern California has turned her kitchen table into an improvised command post where she is enforcing Santa Clara County’s strict lockdown order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Washington, the Nation’s Capital, Moves to Reopen. Washington, the City, Is Not Ready.
description: As the coronavirus hits the White House, Congress and D.C.’s poorest areas, many across the region are asking the Trump administration to proceed with caution.
content: WASHINGTON — As the Trump administration pushes for the federal government to lead the nation in reopening the doors to daily business, the leaders of the capital region that would live with the consequences are fragmented on how to move forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Shanghai Disneyland Reopens With Strict Safety Procedures
description: Limited capacity, face masks and plastic gloves to ride: The opening offers a glimpse of how other Disney parks may cope.
content: The elephants are flying again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Ex-Justice Dept. Officials Lash Out at Barr Over Flynn and Stone Cases
description: The attorney general’s interventions damaged the Justice Department, argued the former officials, who were directly involved in the cases of the two Trump allies.
content: WASHINGTON — Two former law enforcement officials involved in the cases of the onetime Trump advisers Michael T. Flynn and Roger J. Stone Jr. attacked Attorney General William P. Barr’s extraordinary intervention in the inquiries, condemning his moves as detrimental to the rule of law and to public confidence in the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Putting Politics Ahead of Saving Lives
description: “I’m sick. Not from coronavirus. I’m sick of the lies. I’m sick of the lack of empathy,” writes one reader. Others discuss the lack of tests, feeding the hungry and the death toll.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Barbara Babcock, a Force for Women in the Law, Dies at 81
description: She helped Ruth Bader Ginsburg win a federal judgeship. “I would not hold the good job I have today were it not for Barbara,” Justice Ginsburg said.
content: When President Jimmy Carter appointed Barbara Allen Babcock to head the Justice Department’s civil division in the late 1970s, he tasked her with increasing the number of women and members of minorities on the federal bench.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fauci to Warn Senate of ‘Needless Suffering and Death’
description: The risks of reopening the country too soon will be a focus of government hearings on Tuesday. The White House’s new mask requirement won’t apply to President Trump.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert and a central figure in the government’s response to the coronavirus, intends to warn the Senate on Tuesday that Americans would experience “needless suffering and death” if the country opens up too quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: When the Mall Reopened, She Was Ready
description: A chat with a shopping enthusiast in Texas, who didn’t hesitate to return to retail therapy after weeks of lockdown.
content: Malls, retail stores, restaurants and movie theaters sprawled across Texas were allowed to reopen on May 1, for the first time since March 31, when Gov. Greg Abbott told residents to stay home. That included Saks Fifth Avenue, whose Houston and San Antonio shops are the retailer’s only locations in the United States to resume normal business, as of Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iranian Friendly Fire Kills 19 in 2nd Missile Accident of Year
description: One Iranian ship reportedly fired on another during military exercises. It was one more public relations disaster for Iran’s military.
content: For the second time this year, Iran appears to have fired a missile at the wrong target with deadly consequences, raising questions about its ability to control its weapons and increasing tensions in the Persian Gulf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Takes On Employment Bias at Religious Schools
description: The cases are the latest in a series the court has had before it considering the relationship between church and state.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday on how broadly federal employment discrimination laws apply to schools run by churches in two cases that will give the court another opportunity to rule on the proper relationship between church and state, a topic that has deeply engaged the justices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Is Your Office Closed? Compensate With a Workplace Comedy
description: A writer asks the minds behind “Veep,” “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” and other office comedies to join her in pondering what makes the genre so great — and so vital during a pandemic.
content: To begin, a confession: My husband, an essential worker, goes to an office every weekday. He walks about a mile, navigating the sidewalks like a player in some virus-inflected Frogger game, and rides a lonely elevator to an empty 10th floor suite. A staggered schedule guarantees that he works alone — which means no pleasantries, no gossip, no box of doughnuts in the kitchenette just because. And even the thought of this office — bereft, doughnut-less — makes me extremely jealous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: A Pandemic Benefit: The Expansion of Telemedicine
description: Medical practice over the internet can result in faster diagnoses and treatments, increase the efficiency of care and reduce patient stress.
content: Even if no other good for health care emerges from the coronavirus crisis, one development — the incorporation of telemedicine into routine medical care — promises to be transformative. Using technology that already exists and devices that most people have in their homes, medical practice over the internet can result in faster diagnoses and treatments, increase the efficiency of care and reduce patient stress.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fauci to Warn Senate of ‘Needless Suffering and Death’
description: The risks of reopening the country too soon will be a focus of government hearings on Tuesday. The White House’s new mask requirement won’t apply to President Trump.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert and a central figure in the government’s response to the coronavirus, intends to warn the Senate on Tuesday that Americans would experience “needless suffering and death” if the country opens up too quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: When the Mall Reopened, She Was Ready
description: A chat with a shopping enthusiast in Texas, who didn’t hesitate to return to retail therapy after weeks of lockdown.
content: Malls, retail stores, restaurants and movie theaters sprawled across Texas were allowed to reopen on May 1, for the first time since March 31, when Gov. Greg Abbott told residents to stay home. That included Saks Fifth Avenue, whose Houston and San Antonio shops are the retailer’s only locations in the United States to resume normal business, as of Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 5, Episode 2 Recap: Step Up to the Mike
description: Axe finally accepts Mike Prince’s challenge to debate him at his charity conference. Things don’t go quite as planned, especially for Wags.
content: Welcome to the Mike Conference, named with characteristic humility by its founder, decabillionaire Mike Prince. It’s a place for fireside chats that double as vicious duels, for charitable acts that serve to ameliorate an exponentially larger number of uncharitable ones, and for the occasional late-night excursion to a strip club that doubles as a Wagner family reunion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Wary Paramedics in Hot Spots Avoid CPR for Covid Patients
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 11, 2020.
content: “To resuscitate and save one life, and risk five? It’s not balanced.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elon Musk Is ‘Not Messing Around’
description: The Tesla C.E.O.’s dispute with California foreshadows a potential clash between businesses and states over public health measures.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Teenager, an Aspiring Detective, Returns $135,000 He Found’
description: In this lesson, students will learn what decision made Jose Nuñez Romaniz a “hero in the town,” and why he initially didn’t understand why a police officer characterized him that way.
content: Featured Article: “Teenager, an Aspiring Detective, Returns $135,000 He Found” by Mariel Padilla
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: As Contracts Expire During Shutdown, Players and Clubs Ask: Now What?
description: On June 30, most contracts in European soccer expire, and that will put hundreds, if not thousands, of players out of work. For the vast majority, the future is anything but certain.
content: The question Danny Loader must answer over the next two months is a daunting one. Far more daunting than the typical questions most 19-year-olds have to face. It goes beyond where he wants to live or how much he might earn and stretches all the way, ultimately, to what he wants to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Markian Hawryluk
title: Colorado Hair Salons Are Reopening, With New Rules
description: At one salon, beauticians are now wearing face masks and gloves, and no walk-ins are allowed.
content: LOVELAND, Colo. — Last Tuesday, during the first few days that this state loosened restrictions on businesses that were temporarily closed because of the novel coronavirus, Blush Beauty Bar reopened for appointments. It was the first time that customers had been allowed inside the hair salon in 48 days, and the stylists were booked solid. (They remain so through the end of the month.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elon Musk Is ‘Not Messing Around’
description: The Tesla C.E.O.’s dispute with California foreshadows a potential clash between businesses and states over public health measures.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Teenager, an Aspiring Detective, Returns $135,000 He Found’
description: In this lesson, students will learn what decision made Jose Nuñez Romaniz a “hero in the town,” and why he initially didn’t understand why a police officer characterized him that way.
content: Featured Article: “Teenager, an Aspiring Detective, Returns $135,000 He Found” by Mariel Padilla
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can a Landlord Enter a Tenant’s Home if It’s Currently Empty?
description: Landlords cannot arbitrarily take possession of any apartment, whether or not we’re in the middle of a health emergency.
content: Q: My brother died last week, probably from Covid-19. The management company of his Manhattan rental building told me that the family usually has 14 days to empty the apartment, but they would check if anything has changed because of the pandemic. I can’t possibly meet that deadline because I am 79, live in Connecticut and have a medical condition. There is no way that I can risk going to New York City to clear out the apartment and I am reluctant to put anyone else at risk right now. What rights do I have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Alanis Morissette Is Helping Us Meditate. Want to Join?
description: Plus, Michelle Wolf on running in place, Elaine Welteroth on relationships at a distance and more in our live events this week.
content: The coronavirus has transformed nearly every aspect of daily life, but Times journalists are here to keep you informed and connected from home. Below is a selection of our live events this week (all times are Eastern). You can find the full calendar here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Let’s Clean Up the Toxic Internet
description: If we understand how conspiracy theories spread online, we can help stop them.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Taseer
title: In Uzbekistan, Coming to Terms With the Country’s Dazzling History
description: Central Asia was once home to several bustling trade cities. Today, traveling through them reawakens a distant, though not forgotten, past.
content: IT WAS OCTOBER in Tashkent. The broad Soviet-style avenues of Uzbekistan’s capital were lined with chestnut and Oriental plane, their leaves turning russet in the crisp autumn air. This city of 2.5 million had, in Soviet days, which lasted from the 1920s until the country’s independence in 1991, been the premier capital of Central Asia. It is home to more than half of Uzbekistan’s 116 universities, and on that first golden morning in Tashkent, there was something of the glazed perfection of a Soviet propaganda poster in the sight of students in twos and threes strolling down the runway-size avenues. They were dwarfed by the giant buildings that lined the roads — banks, museums and ministries — “Babylonian blocks,” as the English writer Philip Glazebrook, who had been in Tashkent at the end of Soviet rule, described them in “Journey to Khiva” in the early ’90s: “Since the days of Nineveh this has been the architecture of dictatorship and persecution.” And so it was, but after my late arrival on the Turkish Airlines flight from Istanbul, I found myself oddly in sympathy with the ideal, if not the reality, of Soviet life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: The Silk Road’s Enduring Romance, and Eternal Influence
description: Last May, when our known world was one way, we began planning these stories. By last month, when we were finishing work on this issue, the world was another way.
content: LIKE OUR JOURNEY from the womb, or through millennia of evolutionary changes, the Silk Road is a trip that feels elemental to the human condition. We cannot remember, often, how we learned of it, only that knowledge of it seems to be a birthright: It may not be the first story of human movement, recorded or otherwise, but it is the most abiding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: When ‘Valley Girl’ (and Nicolas Cage) Shook Up Hollywood
description: With no money or clout, what started as a cheap exploitation film managed to, like, totally click with a generation — and produce an unconventional superstar.
content: Four shots of nude breasts. That’s what the producers of “Valley Girl” demanded of their potential director, Martha Coolidge. If she wanted the gig — overseeing what was set to be a low-budget, exploitative high-school romp that could lure teen boys like “Porky’s” did — she’d need to make sure the requisite skin appeared onscreen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Richard
title: Doing the Bump With the Belugas
description: An isolated corner of Manitoba is one of the few places left in the world where humans are the outsiders on display for the wildlife to observe.
content: Beneath the waves, two smoldering coals for eyes watched me with an intense, unyielding stare. Pristine white bodies floated up elegantly from the depths, one after another, surrounding my kayak in the open water. Their ghostly pale faces with wide, Joker-esque smiles pushed closer. A long, powerful sound burst up through the air, like a slowly deflating balloon, followed by silence and more expectant staring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sea Urchins Star in This Food Film
description: A new documentary, now available to stream, looks at the history and habitat of the delicacy.
content: The story of the sea urchin, from ocean floor to the dinner plate, is the subject of this vibrant documentary that was released for streaming last week on Somm TV. With commentary from food celebrities like Andrew Zimmern and chefs like Kyle Connaughton, it follows the gourmand’s taste, from ancient times to the present, for the pentagonal gonads of the spiny creatures. It shows their habitat and how urchins off the coast of California are harvested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Joe Biden’s Time in Sarah Palin’s Shadow
description: What two strange months in 2008 taught the former vice president about the politics of grievance, and how that might help him pick a running mate of his own to take on Donald Trump.
content: Joe Biden was getting the hang of being overshadowed. It was not a bad life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Hunger Pains of a Pandemic
description: Empty stomachs can lead to a dangerous desperation.
content: Have you ever been hungry? Truly hungry? Not the hunger one gets in anticipation of a meal, but the kind that pinches the stomach when you know no food is forthcoming. It is the kind of pang you take to bed with you, the kind that greets you when you rise. It is a bitter physical deprivation that gnaws at not only the gut but the spirit. It makes you sad. It makes you angry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Acupuncture May Ease Indigestion
description: Feelings of bloating and fullness were relieved by use of acupuncture needles.
content: Acupuncture may help relieve indigestion, a new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Peisner
title: Jason Isbell, Self-Doubt and the Album That Tested His Marriage
description: The 41-year-old musician is known as one of the best songwriters in the country. And that just may have been the problem.
content: A couple of weeks into coronavirus-compelled self-quarantine at his home on a rolling patch of land 30 minutes south of Nashville, Jason Isbell did something he hadn’t done in more than eight years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jefferson Cowie
title: The ‘Hard Hat Riot’ Was a Preview of Today’s Political Divisions
description: Mayor Lindsay saw a country “virtually on the edge of a spiritual — and perhaps even a physical — breakdown.”
content: This was something genuinely new, and raw. Even jaded viewers tuning in to the network news on May 8, 1970, must have been shocked to see helmeted construction workers waving enormous American flags and chanting “All the way, U.S.A.” as they tore through an antiwar demonstration in Manhattan’s financial district — all of it just days after four students had been shot dead by National Guardsmen during a peaceful protest at Kent State University in Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Shaw
title: They Fled the Coronavirus. Now They’re in Scenic Limbo.
description: Some feel sheepish about their choice to retreat from stricken cities, for intervals that are stretching on. Others have found it liberating.
content: The day before Megan LeCrone, a soloist dancer with the New York City Ballet, turned 36, she got an urgent call from her longtime friend and fellow soloist Harrison Ball. “If we don’t leave now, we’re not going to be able to get out,” he told her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Isabella Kwai
title: China Is Defensive. The U.S. Is Absent. Can the Rest of the World Fill the Void?
description: Smaller countries like Australia are trying to build a new kind of alliance, by first investigating what went wrong in the early stages of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — When Australia started pushing for a global inquiry into the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, no other countries were on board, and officials had no idea how it would work or how harshly China might react.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Employers Rush to Adopt Virus Screening. The Tools May Not Help Much.
description: Symptom-checking apps and fever-screening cameras promise to keep sick workers at home and hinder the virus. But experts warn they can be inaccurate and violate privacy.
content: Bob Grewal recently began testing a new health-screening setup for workers at a Subway restaurant he owns in Los Angeles near the University of Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Masks, State Aid, Ahmaud Arbery: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Richard
title: Doing the Bump With the Belugas
description: An isolated corner of Manitoba is one of the few places left in the world where humans are the outsiders on display for the wildlife to observe.
content: Beneath the waves, two smoldering coals for eyes watched me with an intense, unyielding stare. Pristine white bodies floated up elegantly from the depths, one after another, surrounding my kayak in the open water. Their ghostly pale faces with wide, Joker-esque smiles pushed closer. A long, powerful sound burst up through the air, like a slowly deflating balloon, followed by silence and more expectant staring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sea Urchins Star in This Food Film
description: A new documentary, now available to stream, looks at the history and habitat of the delicacy.
content: The story of the sea urchin, from ocean floor to the dinner plate, is the subject of this vibrant documentary that was released for streaming last week on Somm TV. With commentary from food celebrities like Andrew Zimmern and chefs like Kyle Connaughton, it follows the gourmand’s taste, from ancient times to the present, for the pentagonal gonads of the spiny creatures. It shows their habitat and how urchins off the coast of California are harvested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Macdonald
title: How Animal Observation Can Free Us From Ourselves
description: Watching birds is a way of mobilizing attention, to turn it into a means of imaginative escape.
content: Watching birds is a way of mobilizing attention, to turn it into a means of imaginative escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Robert May, an Uncontainable ‘Big Picture’ Scientist, Dies at 84
description: Trained as a physicist, he applied simple mathematical models to complex phenomena in ecology, epidemiology and financial systems.
content: Robert May, an Australian-born scientist whose mathematical insights blazed new paths in fields as diverse as ecology, epidemiology and the structure of financial systems, died on April 28 in a nursing home in Oxford, England. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Shaw
title: They Fled the Coronavirus. Now They’re in Scenic Limbo.
description: Some feel sheepish about their choice to retreat from stricken cities, for intervals that are stretching on. Others have found it liberating.
content: The day before Megan LeCrone, a soloist dancer with the New York City Ballet, turned 36, she got an urgent call from her longtime friend and fellow soloist Harrison Ball. “If we don’t leave now, we’re not going to be able to get out,” he told her.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Smaller countries like Australia are trying to build a new kind of alliance, by first investigating what went wrong in the early stages of the coronavirus pandemic.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Employers Rush to Adopt Virus Screening. The Tools May Not Help Much.
description: Symptom-checking apps and fever-screening cameras promise to keep sick workers at home and hinder the virus. But experts warn they can be inaccurate and violate privacy.
content: Bob Grewal recently began testing a new health-screening setup for workers at a Subway restaurant he owns in Los Angeles near the University of Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: Abba Eban Was the Last to Hold These Two Israeli Posts at Once. Next: Gilad Erdan.
description: A younger rival to Netanyahu is to become Israel’s ambassador to the United Nations and, in November, to Washington as well.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Monday that Gilad Erdan, an ambitious younger leader of his conservative Likud party, would lead Israel’s mission to the United Nations and, in November, also become its ambassador in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Aide Ousted From White House Reappears Again in Administration Job
description: Ezra Cohen-Watnick’s latest position in the Trump administration is as deputy assistant secretary of defense for counternarcotics and global threats.
content: WASHINGTON — Ezra Cohen-Watnick, the hawkish adviser who has popped up in various Trump administration departments over the past three years, is back in a government building, this time at the Pentagon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Keepnews
title: Jerry Stiller, Comedian With Enduring Appeal, Is Dead at 92
description: In the 1960s, he and his wife, Anne Meara, found success as a comedy team. In the 1990s, he found it again as Frank Costanza on “Seinfeld.”
content: Jerry Stiller, a classically trained actor who became a comedy star twice — in the 1960s in partnership with his wife, Anne Meara, and in the 1990s with a memorable recurring role on “Seinfeld” — died early Monday morning at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert E. Lighthizer
title: The Era of Offshoring U.S. Jobs Is Over
description: The pandemic, and Trump’s trade policy, are accelerating a trend to bring manufacturing back to America.
content: Some say crises don’t so much alter the course of history as accelerate changes already underway. That’s certainly the case when it comes to the coronavirus pandemic and the offshoring of American jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How to Create a Pandemic Depression
description: Opening the economy too soon can backfire, badly.
content: Last week the Bureau of Labor Statistics officially validated what we already knew: Just a few months into the Covid-19 crisis, America already has a Great Depression level of unemployment. But that’s not the same thing as saying that we’re in a depression. We won’t know whether that’s true until we see whether extremely high unemployment lasts for a long time, say a year or more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela K. Johnson
title: The Drive-By, Reinvented
description: One day Southern California will get back up to speed. For now, I’m enjoying the rolling birthday parties.
content: LOS ANGELES — About a month ago, in the middle of the night, someone repeatedly rang my doorbell and banged on my security gate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall Munroe
title: What’s the Sweetest, Crispiest Way to Stay Safe in a Car Crash?
description: It’s made with marshmallows, too.
content: If you’re willing to do the tests to demonstrate it, it really might!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa and Elizabeth Paton
title: Will Shopping Ever Be the Same?
description: As luxury department stores prepare to reopen their doors, global retailers share their plans — and fears — for the future of shopping.
content: When department stores reopen their doors, a familiar whoosh will still greet customers at the entrance: the sudden gust of air-conditioning, the gleam of polished marble floors, the sensation of not really knowing where to start.
source.name: The New York Times
